newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan aims to cut trade deficit to $2.33 bln.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan aims to cut trade deficit to $2.33 bln.

text.p: Pakistan aims to cut its trade gap to $2.33 billion in fiscal 1997/98 (July-June) or 30.86 percent less tyhasn the $3.37 billion of 1996/97, Commerce Minister Ishaq Dar said on Wednesday.

Dar, announcing a new trade policy for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's government in a televised speech, said Pakistan wanted exports to grow 15 percent to $9.575 billion in 1997/98 from the last year's $8.26 billion and keep imports at $11.9 billion against 11.63 billion in 1996/97.
"Export-led growth is the cornerstone of this government's economic strategy," he said.
"Larger and high value added exports will not only help improve the balance of payments but will also provide employment opportunities," he added.
"To lay the foundations of a robust outward-oriented economy, it is now imperative to reverse the anti-export bias in the economic structure evolved over the last 50 years."

He announced a large number of measures aimed at boosting exports, including a provision of adequate export finance to small- and medium-sized exporters via commercial banks and bringing down the general mark-up (interest) rate.
Dar said 50 percent of the duty drawback to exporters would now be paid within three days of the presentation of documents and the balance after verification of customs authorities.

"Machinery (not manufactured locally) imported by engineering units for export-related production (will) be subject to zero rate of tariff upto 200 percent of the export value during the preceding financial year of claimant unit," he said. "This facility would be available on annual basis up to 30th June, 2000."
Local assemblers and manufacturerss of vehicles have been allowed duty-free import of assembly kits, corresponding to the number of their exported units, Dar said.
"There would be no sales tax on imported raw materials, components required for manufacturing goods to be supplied against international tenders," he added.
Dar said exporters would also be allowed to import duty free textile designs, artwork and transparencies upto 0.5 percent of the value of exports.
He also announced duty-free import of raw sugar for further exports after refining. "This would save foreign exchange, utilise idle capacity of sugar mills and result in value addition," Dar added.
Pakistan will also open up the import of gold and silver, which is only allowed to three companiess at present.
"However, foreign exchange for such imports will be privately arranged by the importer as per existing practice," he added.

He said most measures would be effective in a month, hoping the export of non-traditional itemss would register an increase of $500 million in 1997/98 and the traditional exports based on cotton and textiles to contribute an additional $815 million.
